revision.text:
NOTE: The "Command" key is also known as the Apple key.
===At Startup=== *Force Mac OS X Startup - "X" during startup (when MacOS 9 is also installed) *Bypass primary startup - "Delete-Option-Command-Shift" during startup *Startup from Optical Drive (CD/DVD) - "C" during startup *Netboot - "N" during startup *Safe boot mode - "Shift" during startup *Single User mode - "Command-S" during startup *Verbose mode - "Command-V" during startup *Open Firmware - "Command-Option-O-F" during startup *Startup Manager - "Option" during startup *Reset Parameter Ram - "Command-Option-P-R" during startup *Eject CD - Hold down mouse button at startup *Target Disk mode - "T" during startup
===At Login=== *Disable login items - "Shift"
===Screenshots=== * Take Picture of Entire Screen - '"Command-Shift-3" * Take Picture of Selection - "Command-Shift-4" provides a selection tool. Click and drag to select any area of the screen. *Take Picture of Object/Window - "Command-Shift-4, Space" changes your cursor into a camera. Click a window or menu to take a picture of it.
Holding ''Control'' while using any of the above three commands places the screenshot on the clipboard instead of as a file on the desktop.
===Most Applications=== *Hide Current Application - "Command-H" *Hide All Other Applications - "Command-Shift-H" *Toggle Dock Hiding - "Command-Option-D" *Minimize Current Window to Dock - "Command-M" *Minimize All Windows in Current Application to Dock - "Command-Option-M" *Bring Next Window in Current Application to Front - "Command-`" *Bring Previous Window in Current Application to Front - "Command-Shift-`" *Preferences - "Command-, (comma) " *Create new Document - "Command-N" *Save Current Document - "Command-S" *Save Current Document As - "Command-Shift-S" *Close Current Window - "Command-W" *Print Current Document - "Command-P" *Page Setup - "Command-Shift-P" *Undo - "Command-Z" *Cut - "Command-X" *Copy - "Command-C" *Paste - "Command-V" *Help - "Command-?"
===Most Dialogs=== *Cancel - "Escape", "Command-." *Default Button - "Enter" *Selected Button (highlight around button) - "Space"
===Finder=== *New Folder - "Command-shift-N" *Duplicate (File/Folder) - "Command-D" *Make alias - "Command-L" *Show Original of alias File/Folder - "Command-R" *New Window -" Command-N" *Get Info (File/Folder) - "Command-I" *Home Folder - "Command-shift-H" *Applications Folder - "Command-shift-A" *Utilities Folder - "Command-shift-U" *Icon view - "Command-1" *List view - "Command-2" *Column view - "Command-3" *Open Spotlight - "Command-Space" * "Command-Del" - moves selected item(s) to Trash * "Command-Up Arrow" - opens parent directory * "Command-Down Arrow" - open Highlighted icon - [same as double clicking on selected icon] * "Command-space" - show Spotlight search field * "Command-A" - Select All * "Command-C" - Copy selected * "Command-D" - Duplicate seleced item(s) * "Command-F" - open Find * "Command-H" - hide Finder * "Command-I" - Get Info on selected * "Command-J" - toggle Show View Options window * "Command-K" - open Connect to Server dialog * "Command-M" - minimize active Window - [same shortcut works in most apps] * "Command-N" - open New Window - [same shortcut works in most apps] * "Command-O" in Finder - open Selection - [same as double clicking on selected item(s)] * "Command-O' in Other Apps - open File * "Command-R" - selects Original when an Alias is selected * "Command-V" - Paste - [depending on what you have copied depends on how it works] * "Command-W" - close active Window - [same shortcut works in most apps] * "Command-X" - Cut * "Command-Z" - toggles between Undo/Redo last change * "Command-L" - make Alias to selected item(s) * "Command-Option-space" - show Spotlight window * "Command-space" - show Spotlight menu * "Command-Shift-upArrow" - when a finder Window is active, makes the Desktop active * "Command-Shift-delete" - empty Trash, with Confirmation Dialog * "Command-Shift-A" - go to Applications folder * "Command-Shift-C" - go to Computer Folder * "Command-Shift-D" - open Desktop Folder - [does not work for me under 10.4.3 - it is documented in Apple's Help] * "Command-Shift-G" - open Go To Folder dialogue box - allows you to type in a path * "Command-Shift-H" - go to Home Folder * "Command-Shift-I" - open iDisk or opens dialog - part of Apple's dotMac/.mac service * "Command-Shift-J" - launch JavaBrowser * "Command-Shift-K" - open Network Browser - [seems buggy under 10.4.3 - a window must be open, nothing shows up] * "Command-Shift-N" - create New Folder <!-- Not Finder specific --> * "Command-Shift-Q" - log out * "Command-Shift-U" - open Utilities Folder * "Command-Shift-O" - open * "Command-Shift-T" - Add to Favorites * "Command-Shift-Option-delete" - delete Trash, without Confirmation Dialog
===Safari===
*Previous page - "Command-[" *Next page - "Command-]" *Zoom in - "Command-+ (plus)" *Zoom out - "Command-- (hyphen)" *Hide toolbar - "Command-|" *Hide bookmarks bar - "Command-Shift-B" *Show Tab bar - "Command-Shift-T" *Show Status bar - "Command-/" *Stop (loading page) - "Command-." *Add bookmark - "Command-D" *Add bookmark to menu - "Command-Shift-D" *Mail contents of this page - "Command-I" *Mail link to this page - "Command-Shift-I" *Block Pop-ups - "Command-K" *Goto address bar - "Command-L" *Reload Current Page - "Command-R" *New Tab - "Command-T" *Close Tab/Window - "Command-W" *Goto first 9 bookmarks on bookmarks bar - "Command-1-9" *Next Tab - "Command-shift-[ (left sq. bracket) " *Previous Tab - "Command-shift-] (right sq. bracket)" *Autofill form - "Command-Shift-A" *Home - "Command-shift-H" *Actual size - "Command-Option-0" *Show top sites - "Command-Option-1" *Show all history - "Command-Option-2" *Show all activity - "Command-Option-A" *Show all bookmarks - "Command-Option-B" *Empty cache - "Command-Option-E" *Block pop-up windows - "Command-Option-K" *Downloads - "Command-Option-L" *Search results snapback - "Command-Option-S" *Show source - "Command-Option-U"
Develop menu keys (activated from advanced options) *Show Error Console - "Command-Option-C" *Show web inspector - "Command-Option-I" *Start profiling javascript "Command-Shift-Option-P"
===Mail=== *New Message - "Command - N" *Reply - "Command - R" *Forward - "Command - Shift - F" *Send - "Command - Shift - D" *Search mail - "Command - Option - F" *Go to Inbox - "Command - 1" *Go to Drafts - "Command - 3" *Go to Sent - "Command - 4" *Go to Trash - "Command - 5" *Scroll messages - "up/down arrows" (toggle between message and mailbox scroll with "tab") *Scroll within mail - "page up/down" *Go to top of message list - "Command-Shift-Home" *go to bottom of message list - "Command-Shift-End"
===Dashboard=== *Display removal handle for a widget - "Option" and mouse over the top-left-hand corner *Refresh/reload widget - "Command - R" *Reveal/hide the widget bar - "Command -= (equal sign) "
===Services=== Note: These shortcuts can be overridden by the current application, or other services using the same shortcut.
* "Command-Shift-8" - Get Result of AppleScript * "Command-Shift-B" - Send File to Bluetooth Device… * "Command-Shift-F" - Spotlight * "Command-Shift-J" - View in JavaBrowser * "Command-Shift-L" - Search with Google * "Command-Shift-Y" - Make New Sticky Note

revision.comment: /* ''' Example of Time Domain Solution''' */ Removed image with unknown copyright
revision.text:
{{Engineering Acoustics}}
== '''d'Alembert Solutions''' ==
In 1747, [http://www-groups.dcs.st-and.ac.uk/~history/Mathematicians/D'Alembert.html Jean Le Rond d'Alembert]published a solution to the one-dimensional wave equation.
The general solution, now known as the d'Alembert method, can be found by introducing two new variables:
<math>\xi=ct-x\,</math> and <math>\eta=ct+x\,</math>
and then applying the chain rule to the general form of the wave equation.
From this, the solution can be written in the form:
<math>y(\xi,\eta)= f(\xi)+g(\eta)\,=f(x+ct)+g(x-ct)</math>
where f and g are arbitrary functions, that represent two waves traveling in opposing directions.
A more detailed look into the proof of the d'Alembert solution can be found [http://mathworld.wolfram.com/dAlembertsSolution.html here. ]
== ''' Example of Time Domain Solution''' ==
If f(ct-x) is plotted vs. x for two instants in time, the two waves are the same shape but the second displaced by a distance of c(t2-t1) to the right.
The two arbitrary functions could be determined from initial conditions or boundary values.
[http://en.wikibooks.org/wiki/Engineering_Acoustics Back to Main page]

revision.text:
{{recipe}} | [[Cookbook:Bread|Bread]]
This recipe makes dough for a 2-pound (900 g) loaf of bread, or 2 1-pound loaves. It is intended for use in a bread machine
==Ingredients== * 1 cup (heated for about 40 seconds in the microwave) [[cookbook:water|water]] * 2 teaspoons (30 ml) [[cookbook:sugar|sugar]] * 1 teaspoon (15 ml) [[cookbook:salt|salt]] * 2 cups [[Cookbook:Flour|high-gluten (strong) flour]] (bread flour in the U.S.) * 1-4 teaspoon(approximately 30 ml) [[Cookbook:Yeast|active dry yeast]]/ * 1 spoon full of honey
== Procedure ==
# Add ingredients to a 2-pound capacity [[Cookbook:Bread Machine|bread machine]] in the order listed, select dough cycle, and press start. # Remove when cycle is complete. # Preheat oven to 400 [[Cookbook:F|°F]] (200 [[Cookbook:C|°C]]) # When dough is finished, form into desired shape on a floured surface, and place on baking sheet or pizza stone. # [[cookbook:Bake|Bake]] until lightly brown and firm. Cooking time will vary with altitude (20-40 minutes). # Cool and enjoy.
==Variations==
*To make a twist loaf, roll dough into a cylindrical shape with your hands, but make one end of the cylinder thicker than the other. Then divide the cylinder with a knife down the center of the thicker end, creating a ring with a protruding cylinder. Braid and bake. *Brush loaf with an eggwash (1 egg + a scant amount of water) or egg white, melted margarine or butter, or olive oil for a crisper crust. *Sprinkle brushed loaf with minced garlic, chopped herbs, ground spices, grated cheese, ground pepper and/or kosher salt for flavor. *Toss or roll into a flat disc and top with tomato sauce, olive oil, chopped meat, vegetables and/or grated cheeses to create a pizza (bake until cheese is melted).
[[Category:Bread recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Recipes_with_metric_units|{{PAGENAME}}]]

revision.comment: /* Are some of them famous even today? */
revision.text:
== What country did they live in? == The Akkadians lived on the Arabian Peninsula, a piece of land that sits between Europe, Africa, and Asia. Today, many countries share this land, including Yemen, Oman, United Arab Emirates, Qatar, Saudi Arabia, Israel, Jordan, Iraq and Kuwait.
The Akkadians lived on the Arabic peninsula then migrated north which created a big conflict with the Sumerian city-states. The Akkadians finally settled in Mesopotamia. Today this area is part of the Middle East.
== What did their buildings look like? == They built many types of buildings, including large temples and monuments. Their most famous buildings are called ziggurats, which are sort of like square pyramids. The first floor is the largest, and each floor up gets progressively smaller until you reach the top room. The Tower of Babylon is one famous example of this kind of building. The Akkadians buildings were made with handfuls of wet clay. The walls were poorly constructed. One way walls were made was to outline the shape of your house with lumps of clay and let it dry in the hot sun. A faster way was to use wood planks and put a layer of clay between each board. Their houses were shaped like domes, the whole dome was made out of clay.
== What did they eat? == Akkadians hunted fish, duck, and geese. They also ate dates, bread, onions, beans, cucumbers, garlic, and a few other fruits and vegetables. Then they would wash it down with beer or water.
== What did their writing look like? ==
The language used a writing system called cuneiform. Wedge shaped symbols or strokes were carved or pressed into clay tablets with a reed stylus. This writing system was invented by the Sumerians around 3500 BC. Akkadians put their language into cuneiform and many early stories were found preserved in Akkadian text.
== What did they believe? == The Akkadians adopted the Sumerian culture and its ideas. The Sumerians were polytheistic. The Sumerian's Gods An, En-lil, and En-ki lost supremacy to Astral Triad, which consisted of Sin (the moon), Ishtar (venus), and Shamash(the sun).
== Are some of them famous even today? == None recorded because this was an ancient civilization
== What is left of them today? == The Akkadians were Semitic people and their descendants survive today among the modern Arabs and Jews .
== When did their civilization exist? ==
The Akkadian civilization existed during the Mesopotamian times. About 6,000 years ago they lived with the Sumarians and Babylonians. The Babylonians, Sumerians, and the Akkadians all lived in peace with each other. They did not war with the other civilizations, they actually traded. They overran Sumer between 2400BC and 2100BC. Eventually they were conquered by the Babylonians. They still lived in Mesopotamia but eventually died out with the Sumarians.
== External Links ==
*[http://www.wildfowlmagazine.com-sub.info Wild Fowl Magazine] *[http://www.historyguide.org/ancient/lecture4b.html History Guide] *[http://www.vnc.qld.edu.au/enviro/suner/2002-c.htm] *[http://www.brlsi.org/proceed05/antiquity1104.html] *[http://www.ancient.org/cerealfoodsworld/samplepdfs/CFW-51-0004.pdf] *[http://www.wsu.edu/~dee/MESO/AKKAD.HTM]
== References ==
*Mesopotamia: the Mighty Kings. Alexandria, Virginia: Time-Life Books, 1995. *Oxford First Ancient History by: Roy Burrell *Jacob, Heidi Hayes, Michal L. LaVasscur and Bredna Randolph. World Explorer The Ancient World. Needham, Massachuserrs: Prentice Hall, 1998 *Chisholm, Jane. The Usborne Book Of The Ancient World. London: Usborne Publishing Ltd, 1991.
{{BookCat}}
[[de:Wikijunior Alte Zivilisationen/ Akkader]]
{{Wikijunior article stub}}

= My Store =
You can set up many fundamental features in ''My Store''.
== '''My Super Store''' ==
This is the name of the website as presented to the public. The shopper's web browser window displays on the title bar.[[:Image:]]
== Store Owner ==
The name of the store owner. On the web page as the customer sees it this appears at xxx.
== Store Logo ==
This is the logo that appears in the top left hand corner of all pages and on the customer receipts.
== E-Mail Address ==
The main store's email address. On the web page as the customer sees it this appears at xxx.
== E-Mail From ==
When you send an email to your customers this is the email address they will see that it is from. This is also the return email address will be this.
== Country ==
This is the country in which the store is based. On the web page as the customer sees it this appears at xxx.
== Zone ==
This is the zone in which the store is located within that country. xxx.
== Expected Sort Order ==
CRE Loaded can sorts lists of products and other types of lists. You can choose whether they ascend (i.e. a, b, c, d or 1, 2, 3, 4) or descend (i.e. d, c, b, a or 4, 3, 2, 1) here.
Set this value to ''asc'' for an ascending order or ''desc'' for a descending order.
== Expected Sort Field ==
CRE Loaded will sort this field.
You have two choices: ''date_expected'' and ''products_name''. They are self explanatory.
== Switch To Default Language Currency ==
If this is set to ... the default language currency is always used when a customer first arrives at your site.
== Send Extra Order Emails To ==
When your customer makes an order, this option will allow you to specify which emails extra orders should be sent to.
== Use Search-Engine Safe URLs (still in development)==
Sites such as Google dislike the long database derived URLs that CRE Loaded uses. This option will attempt to disguise the URLs, so Google and others are more likely to link to your pages.
You should note that this feature is still in development. Do not use it unless you realise what you are doing.
== Display Cart After Adding Product ==
Customers will see their shopping cart straight away after adding to it. The advantage is that customers are encouraged to purchase goods straight away and are less likely to wander-off. The disadvantage is that they are less likely to add more products to the cart. You may want to test market this feature in order to decide whether you want it on or off.
== Allow Guest To Tell A Friend ==
Do you want to allow people who are not logged-in to tell a friend about one of your products? Absolutely yes!
Do you want to allow spam-bots which are not logged-in to send spam from your servers? Definitely not!
Be careful if you turn this option on. Seek help to keep it from being exploited.
== Default Search Operator ==
When searching the store customers will often type more than one word into the search box. You can make the default search operator '''and''' or '''or''' as follows:
''first search term'' '''and''' ''second search term''
or
''first search term'' '''or''' ''second search term''
For instance if a customer searches for ''baking tray'' and the default search operator is set to '''and''' then all products which contain ''baking'' '''and''' ''tray'' will be included in the search. Similarly if this value is set to '''or''' then all products which contain ''baking'' '''or''' which contain ''tray'' will be included in the results list.
== Store Address and Phone ==
Put your address and phone number here.
== Show Category Counts ==
The server will count recursively how many products are in each category. This is displayed xxx.
== Allow Category Descriptions ==
Turn this on to enable full text descriptions for categories.
== Enable Admin Dhtml menu ==
Turn this on to enable drop-down menus in the admin section. They look pretty cool - but be careful as they don't always work on everybody's set up - the side menus will disappear and you won't be able to change it back if there is a problem.
== Tax Decimal Places ==
This is the number of decimal places that are included in sales tax.
== Show Featured Products on Main Page ==
If you want Featured products to be shown on the main page switch this value on.
== Display Prices with Tax ==
You can either display the product with the price including tax, or the price excluding tax.
== Welcome Gift Voucher Amount ==
When customers register for your store you can give them a fixed gift voucher.
== Welcome Discount Coupon Code ==
Newly registered customers can be given a discount coupon here.
== Category/Products Display Order ==
This is the order in which category/ products should be displayed.
[[Category:CRE Loaded Features]]

{{{1|Welcome, {{PAGENAME}}!}}} {| style="background:white; border:1px solid #abd5f5;; padding:0px; border-spacing:0px; color: #000000;" ! style="background:#d0e5f5; color: #000000;" | [[Wikibooks:Welcome|Getting started]] with Wikibooks |- | style="padding:5px;" | * Wikibooks is a collection of open-source textbooks. Find out [[WB:WIW|what this means]]. * To sign your name (on talk pages), use four tildes, like this: ~~~~ * For help in using the wiki, see [[Using Wikibooks]]. * For information about the community here, see [[Wikibooks Community]]. * Explore, [[Wikibooks:Be bold|be bold]], and have fun! |}
Come introduce yourself at the [[WB:SLN|new users]] page. If you have any questions, you can ask there or contact me personally. * Please also check out the [[Cookbook:Policy|Cookbook policy]] page and the [[Talk:Cookbook|Cookbook talk]] pages. revision.comment: [[WB:REVERT|Reverted]] edits by [[Special:Contributions/183.82.97.201|183.82.97.201]] ([[User talk:183.82.97.201|talk]]) to last version by Avicennasis
revision.text:
== First Name ==
This is the minimum number of characters you allow a first name to have. A reasonable number is 2, any more and people called Jo cannot use your store!
== Last Name ==
This is the minium number of characters that a last name (surname) can have - as with first name 2 is a resonable number.
== Date of Birth ==
This is the earliest date you allow people to use as their date of birth. Of course setting this date too late will mean you cannot benefit from the custom of "silver surfers".
== E-Mail Address ==
This is the shortest number of characters you would like to allow in an email address.
== Street Address ==
This is the shortest number of characters in the street address that you will allow a customer to have.
== Company ==
This is the least number of characters that you will allow a company to register.
== Post Code ==
This is the shorted number of characters to allow when a customer registers their post code.
== City ==
This is the shortest number of letters that you will allow a customer's city to be.
== State ==
This is the shortest number of letters that you will allow for a state.
== Telephone Number ==
This is the shortest number of digits you will allow in the registering customer's telephone number.
== Password ==
This is the shortest password that you will allow registered customers to have. Make this short enough for customers to remember and long enough so that you do not open security risks.
== Credit Card Owner Name ==
This is the shortest number of letters you will allow in a credit card owner's name.
== Credit Card Number ==
This is the shortest credit card number that you will allow.
== Review Text ==
This is the shortest number of characters that you will allow when a customer makes a review.
== Best Sellers ==
This is the shortest list of best sellers that you will display on your site.
== Also Purchased ==
This is the shortest list of products that will be displayed in the ''customers who bought this also purchased'' part of the page when a customer is looking at the front page.
== X-Sell ==
This is the minimum number of products to be displayed in the x-sell box.
[[Category:CRE Loaded Features]]

revision.comment: Revert to revision 490237 dated 2006-06-17 19:36:05 by Jguk using [[:en:Wikipedia:Tools/Navigation_popups|popups]]
revision.text:
== Address Book Entries ==
This is the maximum number of addresses that customers can keep in their accounts.
== Search Results ==
This is the maximum number of search results to return - as many people rarely look beyond the first page of the search this option may save some of your server's power.
== Page Links ==
This is the number of page links to display in xxx.
== Special Products ==
The maximum number of products to display that are on special.
== New Products Module ==
This is the maximum number of new products to display.
== Products Expected ==
This is the maximum number of products expected to display in the products expected box.
== Manufacturers List ==
If the number of manufacturers exceeds this number a drop down menu will be used instead of a list box.
== Manufacturers Select Size ==
Set this option to 1 if you want a drop down.
Set this option to more than 1 if you want to have a list box.
== Length of Manufacturers Name ==
Enter the maximum length of a manufacturer's name.
== New Reviews ==
Limit the length of your customers' new reviews here in characters.
== Selection of Random Reviews ==
You can alter the number of entries displayed when customers are presented with a random selection of reviews.
== Selection of Random New Products ==
You can alter the number of entries displayed when customers are presented with a random selection of new products.
== Selection of Products on Special ==
You can alter the number of entries displayed when customers are presented with a random selection of products on special.
== Categories To List Per Row ==
You can choose number of categories per row customer is presented with a list of categories.
== New Products Listing ==
The number of new products to list in the new products listing.
== Best Sellers ==
Limit the number of products listed when the customer is presented with a list of best sellers.
== Also Purchased ==
Limit the number of products in the list when the site recommends to an item's purchaser products that customers also purchased.
== Customer Order History Box ==
You can control the number of orders in the order hsitory box that is displayed.
== Order History ==
Put the maximum number of orders that is displayed in order history.

{{ #ifeq: {{SUBPAGENAME}} | All Chapters | (This section has not yet been written) | ''This section of the [[Circuit Theory]] wikibook is a [[Help:Stub|stub]]. You can help by expanding this section. ''}} <includeonly>{{#ifeq:{{{example|no}}}|no|[[Category:Circuit Theory/Stubs]]}}</includeonly> <noinclude>:''This template adds page to [[:Category:Circuit Theory/Stubs]].'' {{BookCat}}</noinclude>

{{Circuit Theory/Page}} == Electric Charge (Coulombs) == {{SideBox|'''Note:'''
An electron has a charge of
'''-1.602×10E-19''' C.}} [[:w:Electric_charge|'''Electric charge''']] is a [[:w:physical property|physical property]] of [[:w:matter|matter]] that causes it to experience a [[:w:force|force]] when near other electrically charged matter. Electric Charge (symbol q) is measured in SI units called '''"Coulombs"''', which are abbreviated with the letter capital C. We know that q=n*e, where n = number of electrons and e= 1.6*10-19. Hence n=1/e coulombs. A Coulomb is the total charge of 6.24150962915265×1018 electrons, thus a single electron has a charge of −1.602 × 10−19. It is important to understand that this concept of "charge" is associated with static electricity. Charge, as a concept, has a physical boundary that is related to counting a group of electrons. "Flowing" electricity is an [[:w:Electric_charge#Static_electricity_and_electric_current|'''entirely different situation''']]. "Charge" and electrons separate. Charge moves at the speed of light while electrons move at the speed of [[:w:Drift_velocity|'''1 meter/hour''']]. Thus in most circuit analysis, "charge" is an abstract concept unrelated to energy or an electron and more related to the flow of [[:w:Physical_information|'''information''']]. Electric charge is the subject of many fundamental laws, such as [[:w:Coulomb%27s_law|'''Coulomb's Law''']] and [[:w:Gauss%27s_law|'''Gauss' Law''']] (static electricity) but is not used much in circuit theory. == Voltage (Volts) == '''Voltage''' is a measure of the work required to move a charge from one point to another in a electric field. Thus the unit "volt" is defined as a Joules (J) per Coulomb (C). :V = \frac{W}{q} W represents work, q represents an amount of charge. Charge is a static electricity concept. The definition of a volt is shared between static and "flowing" electronics. Voltage is sometimes called "electric potential", because voltage represents the a difference in Electro Motive Force (EMF) that can produce current in a circuit. More voltage means more potential for current. Voltage also can be called "Electric Pressure", although this is far less common. Voltage is not measured in absolutes but in ''relative'' terms. The English language tradition obscures this. For example we say "What is the distance to New York?" Clearly implied is the relative distance from where we are standing to New York. But if we say "What is the voltage at ______?" What is the starting point? Voltage is defined between two points. Voltage is relative to where 0 is defined. We say "The voltage from point A to B is 5 volts." It is important to understand EMF and voltage are two different things. When the question is asked "What is the voltage at ______?", look for the ground symbol on a circuit diagram. Measure voltage from ground to _____. If the question is asked "What is the voltage from A to B?" then put the red probe on A and the black probe on B (not ground). The absolute is referred to as "EMF" or Electro Motive Force. The difference between the two EMF's is a voltage. == Current (Amperes)== '''Current''' is a measurement of the flow of electricity. Current is measured in units called '''Amperes''' (or "Amps"). An ampere is "charge volume velocity" in the same way water current could be measured in "cubic feet of water per second." But current is a [[:w:SI_base_unit|'''base SI unit''']], a fundamental dimension of reality like space, time and mass. A coulomb or charge is not. A coulomb is actually defined in terms of the ampere. "Charge or Coulomb" is a [[:w:SI_derived_units#Derived_units_with_special_names|'''derived SI Unit''']]. The coulomb is a fictitious entity left over from the [[:w:History_of_electromagnetic_theory#Late_18th_century|'''one fluid /two fluid''']] philosophies of the 18th century. This course is about flowing electrical energy that is found in all modern electronics. Charge volume velocity (defined by current) is a useful concept, but understand it has no basis in reality. Do not think of current as a bundle electrons carrying energy through a wire. [[Special_Relativity|Special relativity]] and [[Quantum_Mechanics|quantum mechanics]] concepts are necessary to understand how electrons move at [[:w:Drift_velocity|'''1 meter/hour''']] through copper, yet electromagnetic energy moves at near the speed of light. {{SideBox|[[:w:Electric_charge#Properties|'''Charge''']] is similar to the [[:w:Rest_mass|'''rest mass''']] concept of relativity and generates the [[:w:Charge_(physics)|'''U(1) symmetry''']] of electromagnetism}} Amperes are abbreviated with an "A" (upper-case A), and the variable most often associated with current is the letter "i" (lower-case I). In terms of coulombs, an ampere is: :i = \frac{dq}{dt} {{SideBox|For the rest of this book, the lower-case J ( j ) will be used to denote an imaginary number, and the lower-case I ( i ) will be used to denote current.}} Because of the widespread use of complex numbers in Electrical Engineering, it is common for electrical engineering texts to use the letter "j" (lower-case J) as the imaginary number, instead of the "i" (lower-case I) commonly used in math texts. This wikibook will adopt the "j" as the imaginary number, to avoid confusion. == Energy and Power == Electrical theory is about energy storage and the flow of energy in circuits. Energy is chopped up arbitrarily into something that doesn't exist but can be counted called a coulomb. Energy per coulomb is voltage. The velocity of a coulomb is current. Multiplied together, the units are energy velocity or power ... and the unreal "coulomb" disappears. ===Energy=== Energy is measured most commonly in Joules, which are abbreviated with a "J" (upper-case J). The variable most commonly used with energy is "w" (lower-case W). The energy symbol is w which stands for work. Work is something good that we, as humans value. From a thermodynamics point of view, all energy consumed by a circuit is work ... all the heat is turned into work. Practically speaking, this can not be true. If it were true, computers would never consume any energy and never heat up. The reason that all the energy going into a circuit and leaving a circuit is considered "work" is because from a thermodynamic point of view, electrical energy is ideal. All of it can be used. Ideally all of it can be turned into work. Most introduction to thermodynamics courses assume that electrical energy is completely organized (and has entropy of 0). ===Power=== A corollary to the concept of energy being work, is that all the energy/power of a circuit (ideally) can be accounted for. The sum of all the power entering and leaving a circuit should add up to zero. No energy should be accumulated (theoretically). Of course capacitors will charge up and may hold onto their energy when the circuit is turned off. Inductors will create a magnetic field containing energy that will instantly disappear back into the source through the switch that turns the circuit off. This course uses what is called the "[[:w:Electric_power#Passive_sign_convention|passive]]" sign convention for power. Energy put into a circuit by a power supply is negative, energy leaving a circuit is positive. Power (the flow of energy) computations are an important part of this course. The symbol for power is w (for work) and the units are Watts or W.

page.title: Engineering Acoustics/Boundary Conditions and Forced Vibrations

revision.comment: [[WP:AWB/T|Typo fixing]], typos fixed: displacment → displacement, propogating → propagating (2), typicaly → typically using [[Project:AWB|AWB]]
revision.text:
{{Engineering Acoustics}}
== Boundary Conditions ==
The functions representing the solutions to the wave equation previously discussed,
i.e. <math>y(x,t)= f(\xi)+g(\eta)\,</math> with <math>\xi=ct-x\,</math> and <math>\eta=ct+x\,</math>
are dependent upon the boundary and initial conditions. If it is assumed that the wave is propagating through a string, the initial conditions are related to the specific disturbance in the string at t=0. These specific disturbances are determined by location and type of contact and can be anything from simple oscillations to violent impulses. The effects of boundary conditions are less subtle.
The most simple boundary conditions are the Fixed Support and Free End. In practice, the Free End boundary condition is rarely encountered since it is assumed there are no transverse forces holding the string (e.g. the string is simply floating).
=== For a Fixed Support:===
The overall displacement of the waves travelling in the string, at the support, must be zero. Denoting x=0 at the support, This requires:
<math>y(0,t)= f(ct-0)+g(ct+0) = 0\,</math>
Therefore, the total transverse displacement at x=0 is zero.
The sequence of wave reflection for incident, reflected and combined waves are illustrated below. Please note that the wave is traveling to the left (negative '''x''' direction) at the beginning. The reflected wave is ,of course, traveling to the right (positive '''x''' direction).
'''t=0''' [[Image:Fixed_t0.gif]]
'''t=t1''' [[Image:Fixed_t1.gif]]
'''t=t2''' [[Image:Fixed_t2.gif]]
'''t=t3''' [[Image:Fixed_t3.gif]]
=== For a Free Support:===
Unlike the Fixed Support boundary condition, the transverse displacement at the support does not need to be zero, but must require the sum of transverse forces to cancel. If it is assumed that the angle of displacement is small,
<math>\sin(\theta)\approx\theta=\left( \frac{\partial y}{\partial x} \right)\,</math>
and so,
<math>\sum F_{y} = T\sin(\theta)\approx T\left( \frac{\partial y}{\partial x} \right)=0\,</math>
But of course, the tension in the string, or T, will not be zero and this requires the slope at x=0 to be zero:
i.e. <math> \left( \frac{\partial y}{\partial x} \right)=0\,</math>
Again for free boundary, the sequence of wave reflection for incident, reflected and combined waves are illustrated below:
'''t=0''' [[Image:Free_t0.gif]]
'''t=t1''' [[Image:Free_t1.gif]]
'''t=t2''' [[Image:Free_t2.gif]]
'''t=t3''' [[Image:Free_t3.gif]]
=== Other Boundary Conditions:===
There are many other types of boundary conditions that do not fall into our simplified categories. As one would expect though, it isn't difficult to relate the characteristics of numerous "complex" systems to the basic boundary conditions. Typical or realistic boundary conditions include mass-loaded, resistance-loaded, damping-loaded, and impedance-loaded strings. For further information, see Kinsler, Fundamentals of Acoustics, pp 54-58.
Here is a website with nice movies of wave reflection at different BC's: [http://www.ap.stmarys.ca/demos/content/osc_and_waves/wave_reflection/wave_reflection.html Wave Reflection]
== Wave Properties ==
To begin with, a few definitions of useful variables will be discussed. These include; the wave number, phase speed, and wavelength characteristics of wave travelling through a string.
The speed that a wave propagates through a string is given in terms of the phase speed, typically in m/s, given by:
<math>c = \sqrt{T/\rho_{L}}\,</math> where <math>\rho_{L}\,</math> is the density per unit length of the string.
The wave number is used to reduce the transverse displacement equation to a simpler form and for simple harmonic motion, is multiplied by the lateral position. It is given by:
<math>k=\left( \frac{\omega}{c} \right)\,</math> where <math>\omega=2\pi f\,</math>
Lastly, the wavelength is defined as:
<math>\lambda=\left( \frac{2\pi}{k} \right)=\left( \frac{c}{f} \right)\,</math>
and is defined as the distance between two points, usually peaks, of a periodic waveform.
These "wave properties" are of practical importance when calculating the solution of the wave equation for a number of different cases. As will be seen later, the wave number is used extensively to describe wave phenomenon graphically and quantitatively.
For further information: [http://scienceworld.wolfram.com/physics/Wavenumber.html Wave Properties]
== Forced Vibrations == 1.forced vibrations of infinite string suppose there is a string very long , at x=0 there is a force exerted on it.
F(t)=Fcos(wt)=Real{Fexp(jwt)}
use the boundary condition at x=0,
neglect the reflected wave
it is easy to get the wave form
where w is the angular velocity, k is the wave number.
according to the impedance definition
it represents the characteristic impedance of the string. obviously, it is purely resistive, which is like the resistance in the mechanical system.
---- The dissipated power
Note: along the string, all the variables propagate at same speed.
[http://www.mcasco.com/p1apsat.html link title] a useful link to show the time-space property of the wave.
---- Some interesting animations of the wave at different boundary conditions.
1.hard boundary (which is like a fixed end)
2.soft boundary (which is like a free end)
3.from low density to high density string
4.from high density to low density string
[http://en.wikibooks.org/wiki/Engineering_Acoustics Back to Main page]

{{Engineering Acoustics}}
== Boundary Conditions ==
The functions representing the solutions to the wave equation previously discussed,
i.e. <math>y(x,t)= f(\xi)+g(\eta)\,</math> with <math>\xi=ct-x\,</math> and <math>\eta=ct+x\,</math>
are dependent upon the boundary and initial conditions. If it is assumed that the wave is propagating through a string, the initial conditions are related to the specific disturbance in the string at t=0. These specific disturbances are determined by location and type of contact and can be anything from simple oscillations to violent impulses. The effects of boundary conditions are less subtle.
The most simple boundary conditions are the Fixed Support and Free End. In practice, the Free End boundary condition is rarely encountered since it is assumed there are no transverse forces holding the string (e.g. the string is simply floating).
- For a Fixed Support:
The overall displacement of the waves travelling in the string, at the support, must be zero. Denoting x=0 at the support, This requires:
<math>y(0,t)= f(ct-0)+g(ct+0) = 0\,</math>
Therefore, the total transverse displacement at x=0 is zero.
- For a Free Support:
Unlike the Fixed Support boundary condition, the transverse displacement at the support does not need to be zero, but must require the sum of transverse forces to cancel. If it is assumed that the angle of displacement is small,
<math>\sin(\theta)\approx\theta=\left( \frac{\partial y}{\partial x} \right)\,</math>
and so,
<math>\sum F_{y} = T\sin(\theta)\approx T\left( \frac{\partial y}{\partial x} \right)=0\,</math>
But of course, the tension in the string, or T, will not be zero and this requires the slope at x=0 to be zero:
i.e. <math> \left( \frac{\partial y}{\partial x} \right)=0\,</math>
- Other Boundary Conditions:
There are many other types of boundary conditions that do not fall into our simplified categories. As one would expect though, it isn't difficult to relate the characteristics of numerous "complex" systems to the basic boundary conditions. Typical or realistic boundary conditions include mass-loaded, resistance-loaded, damping-loaded, and impedance-loaded strings. For further information, see Kinsler, Fundamentals of Acoustics, pp 54-58.
== Wave Properties ==
To begin with, a few definitions of useful variables will be discussed. These include; the wave number, phase speed, and wavelength characteristics of wave travelling through a string.
The speed that a wave propagates through a string is given in terms of the phase speed, typically in m/s, given by:
<math>c = \sqrt{T/\rho_{L}}\,</math> where <math>\rho_{L}\,</math> is the density per unit length of the string.
The wave number is used to reduce the transverse displacement equation to a simpler form and for simple harmonic motion, is multiplied by the lateral position. It is given by:
<math>k=\left( \frac{\omega}{c} \right)\,</math> where <math>\omega=2\pi f\,</math>
Lastly, the wavelength is defined as:
<math>\lambda=\left( \frac{2\pi}{k} \right)=\left( \frac{c}{f} \right)\,</math>
and is defined as the distance between two points, usually peaks, of a periodic waveform.
These "wave properties" are of practical importance when calculating the solution of the wave equation for a number of different cases. As will be seen later, the wave number is used extensively to describe wave phenomenon graphically and quantitatively.
For further information: [http://scienceworld.wolfram.com/physics/Wavenumber.html Wave Properties]
[http://en.wikibooks.org/wiki/Engineering_Acoustics Back to Main page]
------------------------------------------------------------------------------------ Edited by: Mychal Spencer

{{split}}
Please help to build this book by:
# Creating a new page for each unit (see the [http://www.ntis.gov.au/cgi-bin/waxhtml/~ntis2/pkg.wxh?page=80&inputRef=231 Australian National Training Information Service] entry for each unit as a guide) # Providing links to information and resources that will assist learning the unit # Designing assignments for learners to prove competency in the unit.
When designing assignments, please try to design so that the learner's work can also be used as a resources to assist future learners in Wikiversity. For example, To document and prove competency in "''this unit''" please record an interview between yourself and a practising trainer and make the MP3 available on the Internet via a Universal Resource Locator (URL).
= Units =
The following groups of units have been based on the Australian National Training Information Service's training package [http://www.ntis.gov.au/cgi-bin/waxhtml/~ntis2/pkg.wxh?page=80&inputRef=231 TAA04 Training and Assessment] as of October 2005. Proving competency in the following units can lead to a qualification to train and assess in an Australian Registered Training Organisation (RTO).
== Assessment ==
* Contribute to assessment * Plan and organise assessment * Assess competence * Develop assessment tools * Participate in assessment validation * Lead and coordinate assessment systems and services
== Coordination, Management and Quality of Training and/or Assessment Services == * Develop training and/or assessment organisational policies and procedures * Coordinate training and/or assessment arrangements for apprenticeships/traineeships * Lead and conduct training and/or assessment evaluations * Determine and manage scope of training and/or assessment services * Lead a team to foster innovation
== Delivery and Facilitation == * Provide training through instruction and demonstration of work skills * Plan and organise group-based delivery * Facilitate group-based learning * Facilitate individual learning * Facilitate work-based learning * Coordinate and facilitate distance-based learning * Facilitate e-learning * Facilitate action learning projects * Provide advanced facilitation to support learning * Lead and coordinate training services
== Language, Literacy and Numeracy Practice == * Address language, literacy and numeracy issues within learning and assessment practice
== Learning Design == * Use Training Packages to meet client needs * Design and develop learning programs * Design and develop learning strategies * Design and develop learning resources * Research and design e-learning resources * Develop and evaluate e-learning resources * Research and develop competency
== Learning Environment == * Work effectively in vocational education and training * Foster and promote an inclusive learning culture * Ensure a healthy and safe learning environment * Develop innovative ideas at work * Maintain and enhance professional practice
== Training Advisory Services == * Maintain information requirements of training and/or assessment organisations * Undertake organisational training needs analysis * Prepare a tender bid * Manage contracted work * Facilitate group processes
== Imported Units == * Participate in a quality audit * Develop teams and individuals * Analyse and present research information * Promote products and services * Build a virtual community * Ensure team effectiveness * Manage people * Manage industrial relations policies and processes * Prepare budgets and financial plans * Manage budgets and financial plans * Recruit, select and induct staff * Build client relationships * Evaluate marketing opportunities * Manage and monitor business or records systems * Provide careers guidance * Co-ordinate research and analysis
{{Alphabetical|T}} {{Subjects|Human resources}} {{status|0%}}

revision.text:
=Lesson One / ''Lezione uno''= ==Dialogue / ''Dialogo''== : ''Maria'' : Ciao, Giuseppe! Come stai? '{{Listen|filename=Ciao, giuseppe come stai.ogg|title=Ciao, giuseppe come stai.ogg|description=audio name|format=[[Ogg]]}}.' : ''Giuseppe'' : Ciao, Maria! Sto bene, grazie mille. E tu? '{{Listen|filename=Ciao,_Maria!_Sto_bene,_grazie_mille._E_tu.ogg|title=sto bene ti presento bianca.ogg|description=italian pronunciation|format=[[Ogg]]}}.' : ''Maria'' : Sto bene. Ti presento Bianca. '{{Listen|filename=Sto bene ti presento bianca.ogg|title=sto bene ti presento bianca.ogg|description=audio name|format=[[Ogg]]}}.' : ''Giuseppe'' : Buon giorno, Bianca. '{{Listen|filename=Buon_giorno,_Bianca.ogg|title=Buon_giorno,_Bianca.ogg|description=italian pronunciation|format=[[Ogg]]}}.' : ''Bianca'' : Salve, Giuseppe. Come sta? '{{Listen|filename=Salve,_Giuseppe._Come_sta.ogg|title=salve.ogg|description=italian pronunciation|format=[[Ogg]]}}.' : ''Giuseppe'' : Sto bene, e Lei? {{Listen|filename=Sto_bene,_e_Lei.ogg|title=sto bene.ogg|description=italian pronunciation|format=[[Ogg]]}}.' : ''Bianca'' : Sto bene. Arrivederci. {{Listen|filename=Sto bene. Arrivederci.ogg|title=sto.ogg|description=italian pronunciation|format=[[Ogg]]}}.' : ''Giuseppe'' : Ci vediamo! {{Listen|filename=Ci vediamo.ogg|title=ci vediamo.ogg|description=italian pronunciation|format=[[Ogg]]}}.' : ''Maria'' : Ciao! {{Listen|filename=Ciao.ogg|title=ciao.ogg|description=italian pronunciation|format=[[Ogg]]}}.'
==Vocabulary / ''Vocabolario'' == * [[wikt:en:ciao#Italian|ciao]] (informal), [[wikt:en:buon giorno#Italian|buon giorno]], [[wikt:en:salve#Italian|salve]] (formal) — hello, good day * [[wikt:en:come stai#Italian|come stai]] (tu)*? — how are you? (informal) * [[wikt:en:come sta#Italian|come sta]] (Lei)*? — how are you? (formal) * ti presento... — I introduce to you / This is... (e.g. ti presento Bianca - This is Bianca) * sto bene — I'm fine * grazie mille — many thanks * e Lei? (''formal'')? (''informal'') — and you? * [[wikt:en:arrivederci#Italian|arrivederla]] (formal), arrivederci, ci vediamo, ciao (informal) — goodbye, see you later
<sup>*</sup>In Italian, you rarely express the subject pronoun unless you either want to stress the importance of the subject or you want to eliminate an ambiguity regarding the subject.
==Grammar / ''Grammatica''== ===Formal vs. Informal / ''Formale vs. informale'' === In Italian, there are two pronouns that mean ''you'' in the singular. One is informal, to be used with a person with whom you are familiar, and the other is formal, which is to be used with a person of a status superior to yours or with a person you have just met. The informal form is ''tu'' and the formal form is ''Lei'' (note that it is only capitalized here to distinguish between the word for 'she'). The plural of ''tu'' is 'voi', and the plural of ''Lei'' is ''Loro''. Knowledge of the difference between these the formal and informal forms is important because they take different verb forms.
In addition, especially in the south of Italy, you can also use the second person plural ('voi') when addressing an older person to whom you wish to show respect.
=====Exercise One / ''Esercizio uno''===== # Signor Berti has just walked in. He says ''buon giorno'' to you. How do you ask him how he is? # Your friend has gotten a new haircut. When telling them how much you like it, will you use the tu form or the Lei form? # It is your first day of school and your teacher asks how you are. After responding, you wish to say 'and you?'. Which pronoun do you use?
===Subject Pronouns and ''Essere'' / ''Pronomi personali soggetto e ''essere'' === Subject pronouns are used to show the subject of a sentence. In English subject pronouns are: I, you, he, she, it, we and they. Take a look at the following table which contains the corresponding pronouns in Italian.
{|class="wikitable" ! colspan="2" style="text-align:left; background:#dedede"| Subject pronouns |- | [[wikt:en:io#Italian|io]] || I |- | [[wikt:en:tu#Italian|tu]] || you |- | [[wikt:en:lui#Italian|lui]]/[[wikt:en:lei#Italian|lei]] || he/she |- | [[wikt:en:noi#Italian|noi]] || we |- | [[wikt:en:voi#Italian|voi]] || you |- | [[wikt:en:loro#Italian|loro]] || they |- |}
Note that ''lei'' can mean either ''she'' or the formal, singular ''you'', which is used both for masculine and feminine subjects. In written Italian ''Lei'', written with a capital ''L'', is used to represent a formal ''you''. Note also that, unlike in English, ''io'' used for the first person in singular is not capitalized. Subject pronouns (''io'', ''tu'' etc.) are not always used in Italian because, unlike English, the grammatical person is indicated by the declension. Thus, while in English we would say ''I sing'', in Italian we would normally use ''canto'' rather than ''io canto''.
''Essere'' (and also ''stare'') is an equivalent of the verb ''to be'' in English. It is very irregular; the conjugation for the present indicative tense follows:
{|class="wikitable" ! colspan="2" style="text-align:left; background:#dedede"| Essere (to be) |- | io sono {{Listen|filename=io sono.ogg|title=io sono.ogg|description=audio name|format=[[Ogg]]}} || I am |- | tu sei {{Listen|filename=tu sei.ogg|title=tu sei.ogg|description=audio name|format=[[Ogg]]}}|| you are |- | egli/ella è {{Listen|filename=egli ella è.ogg|title=egli ella è.ogg|description=audio name|format=[[Ogg]]}}|| he/she is |- | noi siamo {{Listen|filename=noi siamo.ogg|title=noi siamo.ogg|description=audio name|format=[[Ogg]]}}|| we are |- | voi siete {{Listen|filename=voi siete.ogg|title=voi siete.ogg|description=audio name|format=[[Ogg]]}}|| you are |- | essi sono {{Listen|filename=essi sono.ogg|title=essi sono.ogg|description=audio name|format=[[Ogg]]}}|| they are |- |}
====Exercise Two / ''Esercizio due''==== # How do you say ''you are'' (informal singular)? # ''Come stai tu?'' - Is the pronoun formal or informal in this question? # When I say ''Lei è'', am I talking about you (my close friend) or my teacher? # If you want to say ''Bob and I are'', which verb form do you use? # Joan and Kim are good friends. Would they use ''tu'' or ''Lei'' when talking to each other?
{{BookCat}}
